entry.title: Accessing SAP BTP Core Services APIs Using SAP Cloud Management Service (CIS)
entry.content:
Accessing SAP Cloud Integration (SAP CI) information programmatically has become quite common today.
Whether it‚Äôs iFlows, message processing logs, or deployed artifacts, SAP CI OData APIs make this information easily available, all we need is SAP CI technical user with the right roles.

This convenience often raises a natural question:

Can we do the same for SAP BTP as well?

Can we programmatically access:

  • SAP BTP account details ?
  • Subaccounts and entitlements ?
  • Services and runtime information ?

The answer is Yes, but unlike SAP CI, the authentication and access model for SAP BTP Core Services is fundamentally different.

 

Why SAP BTP Is Different from SAP CI?

When accessing SAP CI OData APIs, authentication is straightforward:

  • Use an SAP CI technical user
  • Assign the required roles
  • Call the OData endpoint

However, SAP BTP Core Services APIs (Accounts, Entitlements, Directories, etc.) do not work this way.

One cannot:

  • Use SAP CI technical users
  • Use basic authentication
  • Directly call these APIs without a management service
SAP BTP protects these APIs using OAuth 2.0 and requires a dedicated management service to act as a trusted client.
And this is exactly where the SAP Cloud Management Service (CIS) comes into play.
 

Introducing SAP Cloud Management Service (CIS)

To access SAP BTP Core Services APIs, SAP mandates the use of: SAP Cloud Management Service ‚Äì CIS plan

CIS acts as:

  • An authorized OAuth client
  • A secure gateway to SAP BTP management APIs
  • The mechanism through which access tokens are issued for Core Services

Once CIS is configured, SAP Cloud Integration can securely access SAP BTP Core Services APIs.

 

Create SAP Cloud Management Service Instance

Step 1: BTP Cockpit --> Subaccount --> Service Marketplace --> Search ‚ÄúCIS‚Äù

Step 2: Create an instance of CIS using the three dots present on the top right of the tile.

Pick ‚Äúcentral-viewer‚Äù as the plan and click on create

You can check the scope of each plan here : SAP Cloud Management Service - Service Plans | SAP Help Portal
Once this step is done, CIS will be available in the Instances column of the subaccount.

Step 3: Now create a Service key for this instance.

As soon as service key is created ServiceKey cis.json file is ready for the download.

The JSON looks like this :

Among the endpoints in the above picture, our focus is on the endpoint, which will give us the details related to SAP BTP Account.

"accounts_service_url": "https://accounts-service.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com"

Now to access this URL, we need to setup OAuth 2.0 Credentials on SAP CI using the details provided in this JSON file.

 

Setting up OAuth 2.0 Credentials on SAP CI

Refer the JSON file and configure the security artifact as shown below.

Token Service URL : <<uaa_url>>/oauth/token
Client ID : << clientid >>
Client Secret : << clientsecret >>
Custom Parameters : grantType : clientCredentials
 

SAP CI Iflow:

We have all the configuration in place, now the most interesting part, lets deploy and test the flow.

HTTP Adapter Configurations:

Base URL: https://accounts-service.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com (can be found in the JSON file)
Resource to fetch information of Global Account: /accounts/v1/globalAccount 

Address: https://accounts-service.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/accounts/v1/globalAccount

Other resources of this API can be found here https://api.sap.com/package/SAPCloudPlatformCoreServices/rest

Credentails Name: As created above

 

Demo:

Lets deploy and execute the flow now:

 

 

Response: The information of the SAP BTP Global Account is seen in the response.

 

Conclusion:

SAP BTP Core Services APIs follow a different and more secure access model. These APIs are protected using OAuth 2.0 and require the SAP Cloud Management Service (CIS) as the authorized gateway.

Once CIS is configured, consuming SAP BTP Core Services APIs from SAP Cloud Integration becomes seamless, enabling automation, governance, and platform-level insights. Understanding this distinction is essential for designing robust and future-ready integration scenarios on SAP BTP.

Hope this helps!

Cheers,

Punith

entry.title: Happy New Year 2026! Got a minute? Tell us what you think!
entry.content:
‚ÄÉ

Hello dear SAP Community! 

We hope this message finds you well and that you're starting the new year with excitement and positivity! As we kick off this fresh chapter, we‚Äôre reaching out to invite you to play a crucial role in shaping the future of our community.

Why Participate?

  1. Shape the Future: Your input will help us understand your needs and preferences, allowing us to tailor our future community initiatives accordingly.
  2. Quick and Easy: The survey takes just a few minutes of your time and can be completed from your smartphone or computer.

How to Join:

Simply click on this survey link and share your thoughts with us! Alternatively, you can also access the survey by scanning this QR-Code:

Rest assured, all responses are anonymous. 

What Happens to Your Responses?

Once the survey concludes, we will carefully analyze the results and share a report summary with you. This will give you insights into how your opinions compare with others and what steps we plan to take next.

Your Voice is Important!

Whether you‚Äôre a frequent community member or this is your first time, your input makes a difference. We‚Äôre excited to hear from you and work together to strengthen our community.

Please help us spread the word and win a meet and greet with Josh Bentley, Head of SAP Community! 

The more voices we hear, the better we can address our community‚Äôs needs. üòäSo please help us and share the survey link with friends and peers! And as a token of our appreciation, helping us spread the word enters you into a draw to win a personal meet & greet with Josh Bentley, head of SAP Community! All you need to do is: share the survey link / QR-Code in social media and comment below this blog post with a link to your social media post that shows how you helped spread the word. 

Thank you in advance for your participation and support!

Warm regards and HAPPY NEW YEAR 2026!
Mynyna

entry.title: Cloud Integration - Synchronizing BTP Accounts into SAP LeanIX using the SAP LeanIX Adapter
entry.content:
Introduction

As IT landscapes expand across cloud platforms, regions, and teams, transparency and governance become just as important as connectivity. Knowing that systems are connected is not enough, you also need to understand what exists, why it exists, who owns it, and how it fits into the overall enterprise architecture.

A very common example of this challenge can be seen with SAP BTP. Organizations start with a few Global and Subaccounts for specific projects, but over time the landscape grows. New subaccounts are created for pilots, innovations, regional teams, and temporary initiatives. Months later, questions start surfacing:

  • How many SAP BTP accounts do we actually have?
  • Which ones are actively used versus idle?
  • Who is responsible for each account?
  • How do these technical setups align with business capabilities and strategy?

Without a structured approach to documentation and governance, SAP BTP landscapes can quickly lose clarity which makes audits, cost optimization, and strategic decisions difficult.

This is where Enterprise Architecture Management and tools like LeanIX play a crucial role.

What is SAP LeanIX?

SAP LeanIX is a Enterprise Architecture (EA) and IT Portfolio Management solution that helps companies visualize, analyze, and modernize their IT landscapes.

Key Functions & Benefits:

  • Application Portfolio Management (APM): Creates clear, up-to-date application inventories to identify redundancies and reduce tech debt.
  • Roadmap & Architecture Planning: Aligns IT strategy with business goals, planning future landscapes for changes like cloud migrations or AI.
  • Transformation Guidance: Helps navigate complex projects, such as ERP (SAP S/4HANA), mergers, and SaaS adoption.
  • IT Risk Management: Manages technology obsolescence and compliance risks, notes the SAP Help Portal.
  • Business Capability Mapping: Connects business processes to underlying applications and technology. 

LeanIX focuses heavily on data-driven architecture decisions, ensuring that architecture is not just diagrams, but living documentation.

Understanding Fact Sheets in LeanIX

Fact Sheets are the core building blocks of LeanIX. They are structured data objects used to represent key elements of your enterprise architecture, such as applications, IT components, interfaces, business capabilities, organizations, and technical platforms.

Each Fact Sheet captures:

  • Essential metadata (name, lifecycle, status)
  • Relationships between architecture elements
  • Ownership and responsibility information

Fact Sheets act as a single source of truth for your architecture landscape.

Why Fact Sheets Matter

Fact Sheets help you:

  • Move away from Excel-based documentation
  • Keep architecture data consistent and up to date
  • Visualize dependencies and impact
  • Support audits, compliance, and informed decision-making

In this blog, we will use Fact Sheets to represent SAP BTP accounts in LeanIX.

Integration Scenario Overview

In this scenario, we build an integration that provides end-to-end visibility of SAP BTP accounts in LeanIX.

The integration flow performs the following steps:

  • SAP Cloud Integration (CI) retrieves details of:
    • SAP BTP Global Accounts
    • SAP BTP Subaccounts
  • The retrieved data is transformed into a LeanIX-compatible structure
  • LeanIX Fact Sheets are then created or updated using the LeanIX Adapter, ensuring the information in LeanIX remains consistent and up to date

This integration is based on SAP Standard Integration Content available in the Discover tab of SAP Cloud Integration/SAP Business Accelerator hub https://api.sap.com/integrationflow/Fullsync_SAP_BTP_Account_Structure . Since the core flow is already provided by SAP, this blog does not cover every palette or step in detail.

The focus is on a key enhancement:
the standard content uses an HTTP adapter to communicate with LeanIX, which has been updated to use the native LeanIX Adapter to meet the use case.

Why Integrate SAP BTP with LeanIX?

As SAP BTP landscapes grow across regions, teams, and projects, maintaining governance becomes challenging. Without visibility, organizations risk unused subaccounts, unclear ownership, and compliance issues. Integrating SAP BTP with LeanIX ensures architecture data stays up to date, provides real-time visibility, and enables informed, data-driven decisions.

LeanIX Adapter in SAP Cloud Integration

SAP Cloud Integration provides a native LeanIX Adapter, making it easier to interact with LeanIX APIs without building everything from scratch.

  • Supports GraphQL variant that allows you to manage FactSheets using standard operations like Create, Get, Update etc.
  • GraphQL variant allows you to specify requirements using Advanced Query feature.
  • Supports REST variant to manage entities like Bookmarks and Settings using CRUD operations.
  • Offers secure authentication via LeanIX OAuth option which employs OAuth authentication.

SAP LeanIX Setup:

Lets start with creating a technical User on LeanIX , because we need the API token to interact with the application

Step 1: In the user profile menu, select Administration, and then go to Technical Users.

Step 2: Create a new Technical User.

Step 3: As soon as you create a technical user, an API Token is generated. Make sure the token is saved as it displays only once

Now, we are all good on Lean IX end.

Deploy this token as a Secure Parameter under Security Artifact in SAP CI

Configurations on SAP BTP.

We make use of SAP BTP Core Services APIs to fetch details of SAP BTP accounts. To enable this, a SAP Cloud Management Service (CIS) instance must be created in the SAP BTP subaccount.

For a detailed, step-by-step guide on:

  • Creating a service instance and service key for CIS
  • Configuring OAuth credentials in SAP Cloud Integration
  • Configuring HTTP Adapter to fetch the information of the SAP BTP Accounts

Please refer to the following blog: Accessing SAP BTP Core Services APIs Using SAP Cloud Management Service (CIS)

SAP CI IFlow:

As mentioned above, the iflow design is referenced from an existing iflow present on Discover tab, you can also locate this on SAP Business Accelerator Hub : https://api.sap.com/integrationflow/Fullsync_SAP_BTP_Account_Structure 

Request Body to create Level 1 Factsheet:

{
  "query": "mutation ($input: BaseFactSheetInput!, $patches: [Patch]!) { createFactSheet(input: $input, patches: $patches) { factSheet { id name type ... on Platform { description name } } } }",
  "variables": {
    "input": {
      "name": "Trail SAP BTP Account",
      "type": "Platform"
    },
    "patches": [
      {
        "op": "add",
        "path": "/description",
        "value": "Global Account FactSheet created automatically by SAP Integration Suite."
      }
    ]
  }
}

In this updated version, I have used LeanIX adapter to connect to LeanIX system, the configuration of LeanIX Adapter is shown below.

LeanIX Adapter in SAP CI has two variants, In this design GraphQL Variant is used

Configuration of LeanIX Adapter

Connection Tab:

 
Parameter
Value
Comments
Address
https://<<domain>>.leanix.net
SAP LeanIX endpoint
Authentication
LeanIX OAuth
To use LeanIX API Token for authentication
API Token Alias
LeanIX
Secure Parameter which was created in the steps above
Reuse Connection
Yes/No
Enable if the connection needs to be reused
Connection Timeout
60000
Specify the maximum waiting time (in milliseconds) while establishing a connection with LeanIX
Respone Timeout
60000
Specify the maximum waiting time (in milliseconds) ) for a response to be received from LeanIX.
 

Processing Tab:

The Objective is create Factsheet on LeanIX, Configure the operation and entity as shown below

All set! lets go for the demo now.

Demo:

We are all set on SAP BTP, SAP CI and LeanIX end. Lets deploy the iflow and check the results.

SAP BTP Account:

This is how the SAP BTP account is structured. Now lets check how the Fact Sheets  are created on the LeanIX side.

SAP LeanIX:

The data is successfully integrated in LeanIX and Factsheets are created.

SAP BTP Account was one global Account and 3 Subaccounts,

Factsheet 1: This sheet shows that the BTP Account has 1 Global Account

Factsheet 2: This sheet shows that the BTP Account has 1 Global Account and there are 3 Subaccounts linked to it (shown as 3 children), You can also see all the relevant tags like ‚ÄúTRAIL‚Äù, ‚ÄúSubscription‚Äù

 

Factsheet 3: This sheet talks about the subaccount ‚ÄúDevelopment‚Äù, it is linked to the Parent Factsheet which is related to the Global Account

Similarly there are two more factsheets for Quality and Production Subaccounts, In total creating 5 Factsheets on SAP LeanIX

With this integration in place, SAP BTP account data is no longer just operational information, it becomes architectural knowledge. By synchronizing SAP BTP Global and Subaccount details into LeanIX Fact Sheets using SAP Cloud Integration and the LeanIX Adapter, we establish a single, governed view of the cloud landscape.

What was previously scattered across platforms is now visible, structured, and actionable. Architects and stakeholders can clearly understand ownership, lifecycle, and usage of SAP BTP accounts without manual documentation or spreadsheets.

But this is only the beginning.

What More Can Be Done?

This opens up several powerful possibilities beyond basic Fact Sheet creation:

  • Maintain relationships between Fact Sheets
    (e.g., linking BTP accounts to applications, integrations, or business capabilities)
  • Enrich Fact Sheets with custom attributes such as cost center, environment, or compliance tags
  • Synchronize lifecycle states automatically based on real usage
  • Detect and manage redundancies across accounts and platforms
  • Enable impact analysis by visualizing dependencies across your architecture

By combining runtime integration data with enterprise architecture governance, LeanIX transforms Fact Sheets from static records into living architecture assets.

 

Hope this helps!

Cheers,

Punith

entry.title: The Curious Case of SAP Community Moderation: A Study in Arbitrary Excellence
entry.content:
The Curious Case of SAP Community Moderation: A Study in Arbitrary Excellence

There's something almost admirable about a system so perfectly calibrated to frustrate its most dedicated contributors. SAP Community's moderation team has achieved what few organisations dare to attempt: the complete democratisation of confusion.

The Algorithm Knows Best

Picture this: you've spent hours crafting a technical blog post. You hit publish. Within moments, the machine learning system ‚Äî trained, presumably, by a committee of caffeinated squirrels ‚Äî determines your carefully researched content is indistinguishable from Nigerian prince correspondence. Welcome to spam jail.

But fear not! The moderators check the filter "regularly." Your content will resurface within 24 business hours. Or minutes. Or perhaps never. The timeline, much like the moderation logic itself, remains charmingly mysterious.

A Tale of Two Blogs

Here's where it gets genuinely fascinating.

A blog post about shell command execution in SAP CPI  ‚Äî

https://community.sap.com/t5/integration-blog-posts/getting-unconventional-with-groovy-part-1-executing-shell-commands-reading/ba-p/14294407#M2049

 

one that, by the author's own assessment, "doesn't reveal 10% of what already existing articles reveal" ‚Äî gets nuked from orbit.

Meanwhile, this gem about terminal access to CPI runtime 

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/terminal-access-to-cpi-runtime-execution-of-shell-commands-on-cpi-runtime/ba-p/13460198

has been sunbathing peacefully on the platform for five years. Five. Years.

And what about this post detailing PGP secret keyring handling 

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/pgp-secret-keyring-in-cpi-the-lost-passphrase-recovery/ba-p/13491284

? If we're genuinely concerned about security implications, one might think exposing cryptographic key management deserves more scrutiny than reading a file via shell script. But no. That one's fine. Perfectly fine.

The logic? There isn't any. Or if there is, it's locked in a vault somewhere, guarded by the same people who decided "Moderator 972001" was an appropriately human identifier.

The Silence Says Everything

When these inconsistencies are raised ‚Äî politely at first, then with understandable frustration ‚Äî the response is instructive in its absence.

No explanation. No acknowledgment. No "we'll look into it."

Just the digital equivalent of being shown the door while someone pretends to be very busy with paperwork.

As one contributor put it: "Is there no accountability left?"

The answer, delivered through elegant silence, appears to be: correct.

Transparency? Never Heard of Her

The moderation team operates with the transparency of a brick wall painted black and placed in a basement with no stairs. Decisions materialise from the void. Appeals dissolve into it.

"Moderator 972001" ‚Äî a designation that radiates all the warmth and humanity of a tax audit ‚Äî can apparently remove two blogs in three days from the same contributor without so much as a form letter explaining why.

One might ask: is this moderator a real person? A bot? A random number generator with delete privileges?

The community may never know. And that, apparently, is by design.

The God Complex, Quantified

There's a specific institutional pathology at play here. It's the quiet arrogance of systems that punish engagement, reward silence, and treat questions about their own behaviour as an inconvenience.

When contributors ask "Are the moderators operating in good faith?" ‚Äî a reasonable question given the evidence ‚Äî the absence of any response tells you everything.

In Conclusion

The SAP Community moderation team has built something remarkable: a platform where the most knowledgeable contributors are rewarded with suspicion, inconsistency, and bureaucratic indifference.

One needn't resort to profanity to describe them. Their work speaks eloquently enough.

entry.title: SAP TechEd 2025 - Nouveaut√©s & Retour personnel
entry.content:
Si Berlin est c√©l√®bre pour une chose, en dehors de ses clubs techno et de ses currywurst, c'est bien pour sa capacit√© √† vous bousculer. Et c'est exactement ce qui s'est pass√© lors du SAP TechEd 2025. D√®s que les lumi√®res se sont allum√©es sur la sc√®ne, une chose √©tait claire : ce n'√©tait pas une conf√©rence comme les autres. Berlin a apport√© son √©nergie, SAP a apport√© son innovation, et ensemble, ils ont offert une semaine qui a laiss√© tous les d√©veloppeurs, consultants et architectes surexcit√©s.

SAP TechEd a port√© un message simple : le futur de SAP sera plus intelligent, tourn√© vers le cloud, et construit pour les d√©veloppeurs. Pour la communaut√© SAP Paris, cet √©v√©nement est plus qu'une conf√©rence technologique mondiale, c'est une boussole. Il nous aide √† anticiper les nouvelles comp√©tences √† d√©velopper. Il nous permet aussi de comprendre les projets et les innovations qui auront un impact sur nous, les consultants, d√©veloppeurs, architectes, et d√©cideurs.

SAP TechEd, fonctionnement

Ce blog regroupe tout ce qu‚Äôil faut savoir sur le fonctionnement de SAP TechEd.

Nouvelles actualit√©s de SAP - The Flywheel

 

SAP r√©invente sa m√©thode de travail en r√©unissant des assistants d'IA bas√©s sur les r√¥les, un Business Data Cloud unifi√© et une SAP Business Suite am√©lior√©e, rendant les applications quotidiennes plus intelligentes, plus intuitives et aliment√©es par des informations en temps r√©el.

Principales annonces qui ont marqu√© SAP TechEd

Introduction √† l'AI Foundation

SAP a annonc√© le lancement de sa nouvelle plateforme d'IA, une couche unifi√©e de fonctionnalit√©s d'IA pr√™tes √† l'emploi dans tous ses environnements. Les principales innovations comprennent :

  • SAP-RPT-1 : un mod√®le relationnel pr√© entra√Æn√© qui fournit des informations pr√©dictives pr√©cises √† partir de donn√©es m√©tier structur√©es.
  • Prompt optimizing : SAP a introduit un assistant intelligent pour optimiser les prompts.

  • AI for Europe : avec SAP, Mistral AI et Cohere North. Une nouvelle initiative qui garantit la conformit√© avec la loi europ√©enne sur l'IA et les exigences r√©gionales en mati√®re de souverainet√© des donn√©es.

Agentic AI

Il s'agit de syst√®mes IA capables de prendre des d√©cisions et d'agir de mani√®re autonome pour atteindre des objectifs complexes sans supervision humaine constante.

  • Agents Low-code dans joule studio / Agents Pro-code dans la BTP
  • Agent interoperability (A2A), Agent Hub & Agent Mining (Signavio)
  • Agentic Orchestration

ABAP Renaissance

Lors du TechEd, SAP a confirm√© que l'√©cosyst√®me ABAP entre dans une nouvelle √®re : plus intelligent, natif du cloud et soutenu par l'IA.

 

  • Introduction de SAP-ABAP-1 : un mod√®le d‚ÄôIA d√©di√© form√© sur les mod√®les ABAP
  • ABAP AI √† partir de la version cloud priv√©e SAP S/4HANA 2021+
  • ABAP Cloud development d√©barque sur VS Code
  • D√©veloppement conduit par agent pour ABAP activ√© via MCP

SAP Business Data Cloud

SAP a √©largi son √©cosyst√®me de donn√©es en renfor√ßant son engagement en faveur de l'interop√©rabilit√© et de la gouvernance partag√©e entre les principales plateformes. Int√©gration avec Snowflake, Datasphere et Databricks

Retour personnel 2025

SAP TechEd √©tait vraiment int√©ressant cette ann√©e, tant pour les annonces que pour les ateliers pratiques. C'√©tait √©galement le premier TechEd en pr√©sentiel depuis la COVID, et √ßa a fait une √©norme diff√©rence. Rencontrer les personnes qui ont travaill√© sur les outils SAP et discuter avec elles est vraiment enrichissant. J‚Äôai pu leur poser des questions sur des probl√®mes concrets que j‚Äôavais rencontr√©s lors de mes explorations.

La plupart des annonces portaient sur l'IA, ce qui est logique compte tenu de l'orientation prise aujourd'hui par le monde de l'informatique. SAP s'est clairement engag√© dans la voie de l'IA et tente de l'int√©grer dans presque tous les domaines. L'IA a tellement √©t√© mise en avant que des sujets tels que Clean Core n'ont √©t√© que tr√®s bri√®vement abord√©s. Selon moi, elles √©taient parfois loin de la r√©alit√© du terrain. Il faudra voir comment tout cela √©volue avec le temps. Une chose est s√ªre : SAP a pris le virage de l‚ÄôIA. Et je pense que nous devons tous le prendre aussi. Mais il ne faut pas oublier que l‚Äôavenir ne sera pas construit uniquement autour de l‚ÄôIA. C'est un outil puissant. Il va changer nos fa√ßons de travailler mais ne remplacera pas tout.

Pour moi, cet √©v√©nement est un incontournable pour tout consultant technique. J'ai beaucoup appris gr√¢ce aux ateliers et aux sessions approfondies. Si vous avez un jour l'occasion de participer √† SAP TechEd, je vous le recommande vivement, car cette exp√©rience en vaut vraiment la peine !

entry.title: SAP Community Hobbies Series: Legos, Motorbikes and Vintage Cars
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

My name is Pierre, and I'm 62 yo.

I worked as a Senior Director, Product Communications at SAP, first for SAP Intelligent RPA as Head of Communications then for SAP Build as the oldest member, by far üòâ, of the Product Communications and Enablement Team, with wonderful colleagues that I miss. ü©µ

Since April 2025, I'm not actively working for SAP anymore, as I was lucky enough to be eligible for the Voluntary Early Retiring Plan launched by SAP in 2024. On one side I really miss the wonderful colleagues I was working with, but on the other side I'm very happy to have more time for my hobbies.

So I‚Äôd like to share a bit about my hobbies as a part of the  SAP Community Hobbies series.

 

First hobby: building Legos

I have always loved building things with Lego: my brother Jean-Fran√ßois and I got our first Lego set when I was 5, and throughout our childhood we played Lego a lot, with our father guiding us. We built houses, castles, and also vehicles with the electric motor etc.

Then in 1978, at age 15, I discovered the first microcomputers, and I turned away a bit from Lego to code my first computer programs.
You will find more about my beginnings as a progammer in the blog post Blog it Forward ‚Äì Pierre Col I published exactly 6 years ago.

It's also because I love building from scratch that I was very happy to work for SAP Build: this low-code + pro-code solution allows business users and developers to very easily build applications, automated processes, and websites.

For Christmas 2024, my youngest daughter offered me the Lego Porsche 911 set: 1458 parts, to build either a Turbo or a Targa. I have completed the building in a few months:

I like this activity very much, because building Legos really helps me relaxing.
To be continued!

 

Second hobby: riding my vintage bikes

You will understand that I'm a petrolhead. üòâ

First, I have always been into motorbikes, because my father was a biker.

From Norton...

In 1973, when I was 10 yo, he sold the Norton 88 I've ever seen in the garage to buy a magnificent  '1970 Norton Commando.

And every morning he was driving me to the high school, on the way to his work. You can easily imagine how proud I was...

My father always kept this bike in his garage, riding it until he was 75 yo. When I was visiting my parents, I regularly did some small tours on the Norton to keep it up and running.

When my father passed, almost 4 years ago, in accordance with my brother I inherited his bike. I did not ride it since then, and I will spend some time this Spring to restart it and ride it again in the countryside around Lyon...

You can hear the wonderful sound of the Norton Twin roaring here:

... to Honda...

In 1981, my first motorbike was a Honda 750 Four. With 67 hp for 220 kg, it was for me an incredibly powerful bike. In 1987 I bought a Honda CB 900 Bol d'Or which I still own:

I lent it in 1997 to an uncle living in Grenoble, he stills ride it but as he is 75yo now I imagine that he won't ride it for very long and I should get the 900 Bol d'Or back in my garage in a couple of years.

... and finally to Ducati

Since 1997, I ride Ducati motorbikes. It started with a 916, then I had a 350 Mark3 Desmo, a 900 Supersport, a 998 S, a Desmosedici RR and a Panigale 1299 R Final Edition. Yes, I really like fast red bike made in Bologna!

The Panigale Final Edition, with 209 hp for 168 kg, was the most powerful and amazing bike I'ev ever ridden. Indeed, even if it was a MotoGP replica with a V4 engine revving up to 14,200 rpm, the Desmosedici RR was not as efficient as the Panigale...

And I really enjoyed the very light and agile '1973 350 Mark3 Desmo I had during a few years, riding it on teh road as on tracks:

Unfortunately, fancy bikes attract thieves: bought in 1997, my 916 was stolen in 1999. My 998 S bought in 2002 and my rare Desmosedici RR #282 bought in 2007 were stolen in 2011. And my Panigale 1299 R Final Edition #322 bought in 2017 was stolen in 2023.

After some bastards stole my Panigale, I refurbished my good old '1994 900 Supersport which I bought in 2000, and lent to a friend from 2004 to 2019. I'm really enjoying riding this light (180 kg) and powerful enough (80 hp) bike on the curvy road in the hills, one hour northwest from Lyon:

 

Third hobby: driving my vintage 911 Porsche cabriolet

In 2011, right after insurance reimbursed my stolen Desmosedici RR, a good friend of mine decided to sell his 1990 Porsche 911 Carrera 2 cabriolet. It was the same car that hank Moody was driving in "Californication", but in better shape, with 135,000 km on the odometer. üòâ

We quickly had a deal, and since more than 14 years I enjoy riding this vintage car, in any weather condition. I just passed 180,000 km and it works perfectly fine. According to my mechanic, my Porsche could reach 250,000 km without any trouble, and as I drive less than 5,000 km per year, for sure it will survive me:


As my wife will be very busy in May 2026, I decided that I will do a "5,000 km in 3-4 weeks" road trip across Central Europe in my Porsche 911: I will pay a visit to my former colleagues in Walldorf, Berlin and maybe a few other cities in Germany before heading to Poland, Hungary, Slovakia, Czech Republic, Austria, Switzerland...

 

Feel free to say hello if you would like me to pay you a visit, between May 1st and May 23: I will be more than happy to let you drive my Porsche in your neighborhood! üòä

entry.title: SAP Community Hobbies Series: Writing Between Silence and Experience
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

My name is Hakan. I‚Äôm a husband and a father, and my two girls are my greatest inspiration in life. I work as an Expert in SAP HANA Solution Support, and today I‚Äôd like to share a bit about my hobby as part of the SAP Community Hobbies series. Alongside the technical world, one constant has stayed with me since my youth: writing. Writing is not a project for me, but a state of mind. It‚Äôs the moment when experiences, thoughts, and encounters begin to take shape, whether they come from everyday life or from situations far outside the comfort zone.
 

Taking a moment to enjoy the view over Lake L√ºnersee after a long glacier climb.

Over the years, writing has become the place where movement turns into reflection, intensity into clarity, and silence into meaning.
 
 
A quiet moment in the Mongolian landscape, letting distance and silence speak.
 

How and when did you start this hobby? What sparked your interest?
I started writing very early, long before my notes turned into books. Even as a teenager, I wanted to capture what life does to me, traveling, people, nature, silence, and also the intense or challenging moments. I lived a fast and intense life: mountains, horses, archery, film and stunt projects, traveling through remote regions, motorcycling, martial arts, and even periods where I spent time forging metal and making knives. 


Forging metal taught me focus, patience, and respect for the process.



These were moments that demanded absolute focus. For a period of time, I even lived as a monk, an experience that taught me the value of silence and observation. All of this leaves traces. Writing became the place where I could sort those impressions and give them meaning.
 
 
What do you love most about your hobby?
Writing connects the outer world with the inner one. It is also a form of relaxation for me, a mental reset. When I stand on a mountain or ride my motorcycle, that‚Äôs when the clearest thoughts come. In challenging situations, my mind switches into deep concentration, and those moments often become the source of later inspiration. Writing shows me what a moment truly meant and preserves something that would otherwise fade.
 

In the Alps, moving through terrain that demands focus and trust.
 
 
What challenges have you faced, and how did you overcome them?
The biggest challenge is honesty, not toward others, but toward yourself. Writing confronts you with topics you may not immediately have words for. And then there is perfectionism: the belief that something must be ‚Äúperfect‚Äù before you share it. I learned that authenticity matters more than perfection. Sometimes an unfinished thought touches more deeply than a polished one.
 
 
What has been your proudest moment or most meaningful experience?
Several readers told me that my writing expressed feelings they had carried for years but couldn‚Äôt articulate. Some said they had to pause because the words were emotionally overwhelming. Knowing that something I first wrote only for myself could give someone else comfort or clarity is incredibly meaningful to me.
 

Balance, patience, elevation.
 
 
What tools or resources would you recommend to beginners?
A pen. A digital document. A quiet moment. You don‚Äôt need more than that. Technology plays only a small role. What matters is interest, openness, and the willingness to reflect. In both writing and coaching, the approach is less about technique and more about mindset.
 
 
What tips would you give someone who wants to start?
Don‚Äôt wait until you feel ready. Perfection is the biggest enemy of beginning. Write for yourself, not for others. Curiosity is the driving force behind everything, writing, learning, and being human. And remember: your experiences are your greatest raw material. Take them seriously.
 
 
This is where thoughts settle, after the climb.
 
 
How do you continue learning and developing in your hobby?
I learn by experiencing. I travel, observe, listen, try new things, and actively seek new impressions. Whether in workshops, in nature, in conversations, or on the road, every moment contains the potential to learn something. Writing helps me make sense of those experiences. Coaching complements this because it teaches me to listen more deeply, to perceive more subtly, and to shift perspectives. Together, these practices give me a level of clarity I didn‚Äôt have before.
 
 
Are there any misconceptions about your hobby that you‚Äôd like to correct?
Many people think writing is a special talent. For me, it is more about attention and courage. And coaching is often mistaken for consulting. Coaching is not about giving answers, it‚Äôs about accompanying people so they can find their own. Both require presence, not perfection.
 
 
Where can people learn more about this hobby?
Books, podcasts, and communities are great places to start, but the best learning happens when you begin writing yourself. Five minutes a day can open a door.
 

A moment of trust.
 
 
How do you see the connection between your hobby and the SAP world?
In my work in Support, two things are constant: complexity and humanity. Writing and coaching help me connect both.
Writing sharpens clarity and expression. Coaching sharpens perception and understanding. Together, they improve how I communicate with customers and colleagues, how I assess situations, and how I share knowledge, whether in KBAs, conversations, or team coaching sessions. At the end of the day, behind every technical challenge stands a person with a concern. And that‚Äôs exactly where my two worlds meet.
 
Coming up next 
I‚Äôm happy to pass the baton to @Sumaiya, the next member of our SAP Community, who will share her hobby of home gardening and what inspires her beyond work.

Looking forward to discovering many more stories in this series.

Best regards,
Hakan

entry.title: Call for Speakers ‚Äì SAP Inside Track NRW
entry.content:
Call for Speakers ‚Äì SAP Inside Track NRW

After several years without a regional SAP Inside Track in our area, it‚Äôs time to bring the community back together. Therefore We are excited to announce SAP Inside Track NRW 2026 ‚Äî and we‚Äôre now opening the Call for Speakers. Some of you may remember the legendary sitPOTT from 7 years ago. Those events showed how strong, curious, and hands‚Äëon the SAP community in NRW can be. We want to build on that spirit: informal, practical, and full of real project experience.

 

What we‚Äôre looking for

We welcome contributions from across the SAP universe, including but not limited to:

  • SAP BTP, CAP, UI5, ABAP, Integration Suite
  • Analytics, Data & AI, Security, Cloud Operations
  • Project insights, architecture decisions, lessons learned
  • Demos, prototypes, experiments, or ‚Äúthis is what we tried and how it went‚Äù stories

Whether you have spoken at many events or this would be your first time on stage if you have something worth sharing, we‚Äôd love to hear from you.

 

Session format

  • Duration: 30‚Äì40 minutes or 15-20 Minutes.
  • Format: Presentation, live demo, interactive session ‚Äî whatever fits your topic
  • Language: English

 

Event details

  • Event: SAP Inside Track NRW
  • Date: 13. Juni 2026
  • Location: On-Site Adesso Dortmund

 

How to submit your session

Please utilize the following Microsoft Form to submit a Topic Call for Speakers: SAP Inside Track NRW.

entry.title: SAP Inside Track NRW
entry.content:
We‚Äôre bringing a regional SAP Inside Track back to NRW, and we‚Äôd love to see you there. After the memorable sitPOTT from soon to be 7 years ago, it‚Äôs time to revive that spirit of learning, networking, and hands on exchange. SAP Inside Track NRW will be a day shaped by the community: practical sessions, real project insights, and plenty of opportunities to connect with people who work with SAP technologies every day.

 

What to expect

  • A full day of sessions from community speakers
  • Topics across SAP BTP, ABAP, UI5, Integration, Analytics, Security, and more
  • Space for discussions, questions, and sharing your own experiences
  • A relaxed atmosphere ‚Äî no suits required
  • Networking with familiar faces and new ones

 

Event details

  • Event: SAP Inside Track NRW
  • Date: June 13, 2026
  • Location: On-Site Adesso Dortmund
  • Registration: Will be opened soon
  • Admission: free

 

Who should join

Whether you‚Äôre deep into SAP or just curious about what‚Äôs happening in the ecosystem, you‚Äôre welcome:

  • Developers
  • Architects
  • Consultants
  • Students
  • Tech enthusiasts
  • Community veterans (including those who still remember sitPott)

 

Why attend

SAP Inside Tracks are built by the community, for the community. They‚Äôre not polished marketing events. They‚Äôre places where people speak openly about what works, what doesn‚Äôt, and what they‚Äôve learned along the way. If you enjoy practical insights more than glossy slides, you‚Äôll feel right at home.

Here‚Äôs what makes attending worthwhile:

  • Practical experience instead of theory Speakers talk about what they‚Äôve actually built, broken, fixed, or learned along the way. No slideware, no buzzwords - just real insights you can take back to work the very next day.
  • Learning beyond your own SAP bubble Whether your focus is BTP, ABAP, UI5, Integration, Analytics, or Security, the sessions are designed to widen your view and connect the dots between disciplines.
  • Open exchange with experts and peers Ask questions, challenge ideas, and get honest answers from people who deal with the same problems you do.
  • A relaxed and welcoming setting Inside Tracks are deliberately informal. No suits, no stage personas, no pressure just people who enjoy sharing knowledge and learning from each other.
  • Networking that happens naturally Conversations start over coffee, during breaks, or while someone shows a quick demo on their laptop. Many long standing community connections began exactly like this including at the old sitPOTT
  • Fresh ideas for your own projects Seeing how others approach challenges often sparks new ways of thinking. Many attendees leave with ideas they hadn‚Äôt even considered before.
  • Reconnecting the NRW SAP community It‚Äôs been a long time since the last event in NRW. This event is about bringing that spirit back and giving the regional SAP community a place to meet, exchange, and grow again.

entry.title: Pix Automatic: How Brazil Is Redefining Recurring Payments ‚Äî and What This Means for SAP
entry.content:
Brazil‚Äôs Pix ecosystem continues to evolve at remarkable speed. After transforming instant payments, the Pix Automatic initiative marks a decisive step toward fully digital, API-driven recurring payments, challenging traditional direct debit models and opening new opportunities for ERP and SAP-based environments.

Pix Automatic is not just a new payment option. It represents a shift in how recurring financial processes are designed, authorized, and integrated.

What Is Pix Automatic?

Pix Automatic enables recurring payments through a single customer authorization, executed automatically on predefined dates, using the Pix infrastructure.

In practical terms, it combines:

  • The convenience of direct debit
  • The speed and availability of Pix
  • A modern, API-first architecture

Typical use cases include:

  • Utilities (energy, water, telecom)
  • Subscriptions and memberships
  • Education fees
  • Insurance and recurring services

Once authorized, payments occur automatically, within limits defined by the customer (amount, frequency, validity).

Why Pix Automatic Is a Game Changer

For customers

  • One-time digital authorization
  • Full control (limits, cancellation at any time)
  • No dependence on cards or legacy debit agreements

For companies

  • Reduced churn and late payments
  • Lower operational costs compared to boletos
  • Access to customers without credit cards
  • Real-time settlement and reconciliation

For banks and ERPs

  • API-based orchestration instead of file-based processing
  • Event-driven payment flows
  • Real-time visibility over execution and failures

The Impact on SAP Landscapes

Traditional recurring payment models in SAP often rely on:

  • Batch processing
  • File exchanges
  • Rigid bank-specific configurations

Pix Automatic changes this paradigm. In SAP environments (ECC or S/4HANA), Pix Automatic enables:

  • I-based payment initiation
  • Real-time payment status feedback
  • Immediate posting and reconciliation
  • Reduced dependency on classic payment files and bank formats

This evolution aligns naturally with:

  • Event-driven architectures
  • Clean Core principles
  • Cloud-first integration strategies

From Concept to Reality: Pilot Projects Matter

While the regulatory framework is defined by the Central Bank of Brazil, real innovation happens in pilot projects, where banks, technology partners, and customers test real-life scenarios.

A strong example applied to SAP is the Pix Automatic API pilot being developed by Santander Brazil in partnership with a SAP Consulting Company.

Why this pilot is relevant:

  • Focus on SAP-native integration
  • Direct consumption of Pix Automatic APIs
  • Real-time orchestration between SAP and bank systems
  • No reliance on traditional payment runs or file-based interfaces
  • Designed for scalability across multiple business scenarios

This type of initiative demonstrates that Pix Automatic is not theoretical ‚Äî it is enterprise-ready and already being shaped for mission-critical ERP processes.

A Strategic Perspective

Pix Automatic is more than a payment feature. It is a signal that:

  • Banking is becoming API-centric
  • ERP systems must be event-aware
  • Finance processes are moving from batch to continuous execution

For SAP customers, this means rethinking:

  • How recurring receivables are designed
  • How bank integration is architected
  • How finance operations can become more automated and resilient

Those who start experimenting now ‚Äî through pilots and controlled rollouts ‚Äî will be better positioned as Pix Automatic becomes mainstream.

Final Thoughts

Pix transformed instant payments. Pix Automatic is set to transform recurring payments.

And projects with some banks and SAP Consulting Companies show that the future of finance integration is already being built ‚Äî API by API, event by event, directly into SAP.

References

  • Central Bank of Brazil ‚Äî Pix and Pix Automatic regulatory framework
  • Banco Central do Brasil ‚Äî Open Finance and Pix evolution
  • Santander Brazil ‚Äî Pix innovation initiatives
  • Makevalue ‚Äî SAP integration and banking API projects
  • Industry articles on Pix Automatic and recurring payments (2024‚Äì2025)

entry.title: SAP Community Voice: 2026 starts with SAP Champions posts, AI tips and survey to give your opinion!
entry.content:
Happy New Year!  

Our Community Voice is back, and we are more than happy to be present for our SAP Community in 2026. We hope our members got to enjoy some relaxing and festive times and that you are feeling rested and prepared to start this year with the right attitude. 2026 is going to be full of amazing moments and opportunities to keep learning, connecting, and growing our community all over the world. 

To start the year right, we collected some of the great highlights that have already been happening in the first two weeks of January. Very insightful blog posts about new features and recommendations for the best use of SAP technologies, a nice opportunity to explore what is new on our platform, and a look at how our SAP Mentors and Champions have been collaborating within the SAP Community, plus all the great events coming this year! 

Let‚Äôs dive in! 

Featured Blog Posts 

SAP Integration Suite New Features Released at the End of 2025 

In Q4 of 2025, SAP Integration Suite delivered great new features, such as AI-powered recommendations that simplify troubleshooting and streamlined connectivity with top platforms like Amazon Kinesis and Box. SAP¬¥s Maiara Ellwanger recently posted a blog post covering the details of these innovations, along with information on new dataspace integration packages, data center availability in new locations, event-driven integrations, B2B interchanges in Trading Partner Management, and new features in Process Integration. Make sure to check out her blog post, as it includes all the details you need to boost your operational efficiency. 

Read Maiara Ellwanger Blog Post here 

Synchronizing BTP Accounts into SAP LeanIX 

One of the main pillars of IT landscape expansion is maintaining transparency and governance. It is important not only to know how systems are connected, but also to understand what exists, why it exists, who owns it, and how it fits into the overall enterprise architecture. SAP Champion Punith Oswal, explains in his latest blog post how LeanIX plays a crucial role with Enterprise Architecture Management, considering that LeanIX focuses heavily on‚ÄØdata-driven architecture decisions, ensuring that architecture is not just diagrams, but‚ÄØliving documentation. If you want to have a full explanation on how the SAP BTP accounts works in LeanIX and the details on the process (including very helpful images, to make your life even easier finding the configurations), this content is a must read.  

Read Punith Oswall Blog Post here 

Tips on How to Start 2026 with SAP¬¥s AI offer 

Generative AI is more omnipresent than ever in daily lives, and according to SAP¬¥s Leo Irudayam the key to successful AI adoption is a useful case, with the right technology and people. In his blog post, he makes AI tools tangible and understandable by sketching an AI-assisted process of vehicle onboarding, showing how it can be automated by leveraging different AI tools offered by SAP within the Business AI portfolio. Leo also explores SAP¬¥s own foundational model RPT-1 and agentic tasks with Joule Studio. He concludes with a reminder that SAP Document AI is a leader in document processing with inbound and outbound channels, and SAP AI Core a powerful AI orchestration service at low costs each. 

Read Leo Irudayam Blog Post here 

Different approach: UI5 Library Use on BTP by Bundling Libraries at Build Time 

SAP Champion Mio Yasutake published a great blog post presenting valuable tools for simplifying UI5 Library use on BTP, considering two different approaches (with and without CDM) and the benefits and limitations of deploying libraries independently. The highlight of her post is an alternative approach: Bundling the Library at Build time. She explains that the main advantage of this approach are the simpler application configuration and the removal of dependencies on resources defined by the library, such as destinations or HTML5 app host service instances. Mio provides a detailed step-by-step guide with images and all the necessary code. We highly recommend checking it out! 

Read here Mio Yasutake Blog Post here 

Community News 

Tell us what you think and win a virtual meet and greet with Josh Bentley 

We want to hear what you think! SAP Community Advocate Mynyna Chau, recently opened a survey (click here to participate), so our Community Team knows your thoughts, needs and preferences. This is our way to tailor our future community initiatives accordingly, but also because we believe that your input makes a difference. The survey takes just a few minutes of your time and can be completed from your smartphone or computer. Once the survey concludes, we will carefully analyze the results and share a report summary with you.  

And as a token of our appreciation, helping us spread the word enters you into a draw to win a virtual meet & greet with Josh Bentley, head of SAP Community! All you need to do is share the survey link / QR-Code in your social media and comment on Mynyna¬¥s Blog Post here with a link to your social media post that shows how you helped spread the word.‚ÄØ 

Hobbies Series: Passion for Writing

The holiday season can be a wonderful opportunity to relax and be available for activities that are often left behind during normal routines. These breaks also allow us to discover hobbies that keep our minds engaged with things we love. At the beginning of this month, SAP Community members shared insights into their favorite activities as part of our Hobbies Series. SAP¬¥s Hakan Haslaman wrote about his passion for writing (blog post here), describing it to shape his experiences and thoughts, whether from everyday life or situations far outside his comfort zone. He shared valuable insights into writing and the topics he enjoys most. He concludes by explaining that in his work in Support, two things are constant: complexity and humanity. And writing and coaching helps him to connect both.  

Events 

Reminder of SAP ALM Summit North America 2026 

As we have previously mentioned before, we would like to remind everyone about the upcoming SAP ALM Summit North America 2026. This event is the chance to boost your ALM value by learning from real-life customer experiences. Expand your knowledge through hands-on labs and attending expert-led sessions.‚ÄØ Some of the amazing speakers that will be presenting at the event are Tim Steuer - VP Customer Communications & Relations SAP SE, S√∂ren Ruder-‚ÄØHead of Customer Experience & Solutions (CXS)‚ÄØSAP SE, Joshua Greenbaum-‚ÄØPrincipal of Enterprise Applications Consulting EAC and Todd Crandall-‚ÄØHead of Customer Services & Delivery SAP North America. Make sure to register for the event here:‚ÄØSAP ALM Summit NA 2026.‚ÄØ 

This year Upcoming Events  

Time flies, and we are already in the middle of January 2026. It is time to organize yourself and book all the great events you cannot miss this year. Check out the list below to see the events already scheduled for 2026:‚ÄØ 

  • 20 of January: SAP CodeJam -‚ÄØBuild AI services using the CAP and Generative AI Hub (Bielefeld, Germa...‚ÄØ 
  • 21 of January: SAP CodeJam‚ÄØ-‚ÄØGetting started with Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core ( Hyderabad, India )‚ÄØ 
  • 22 of January: SAP CodeJam ABAP: SAP BTP, ABAP Environment & RAP ( Hyderabad, India )‚ÄØ 
  • 23 of January:‚ÄØSAP Stammtisch Wroclaw - January Edition! (Registration is closed)‚ÄØ 
  • 29 of January:‚ÄØSAP Build: Advanced Event Mesh - Event based SAP Build Process Automation (Bengaluru, India)‚ÄØ 
  • 09 of February:‚ÄØBuild AI services using the CAP and Generative AI Hub (Pune, India)‚ÄØ 
  • 26 of February:‚ÄØ‚ÄØBuild AI services using the CAP and Generative AI Hub (Gent, Belgium)‚ÄØ 
  • 14 of March: SAP Inside Track Joinville 2026 ‚Äì Brasil‚ÄØ 
  • 17 of March:‚ÄØSAP TALK WOMEN CWB 2026- Curitiba, Brasil‚ÄØ 
  • 14 - 16 of April: SAP ALM Summit NA 2026- Pennsylvania, United States 
  • 26 of September: SAP Inside Track Porto 2026 - Portugal‚ÄØ 
  • 31 of October: SAP Inside Track Fortaleza 2026- Brasil‚ÄØ‚ÄØ

entry.title: SAP Inside Track Melbourne - Full Day 14th Mar 2026 - Call for Speakers
entry.content:
Happy New Year SAP Melbourne Community , hope you all had a great time off and are fully refreshed and ready for an Awesome 2026

We had a great 2025 with around 9 catch up events to learn and meet the SAP Melbourne Community

Would like to reintroduce a full day event on 14th Mar 2026. 

Please get intouch if you would like to present at the upcoming event. Please send your expression of interest to sapsitmelbourne@gmail.com or you can ping me on 0405083265 

Catch you all soon 

Cheers, 

Sai

–¶–µ –¥–∞—î –º–æ–∂–ª–∏–≤—ñ—Å—Ç—å —è–∫ —É–∫—Ä–∞—ó–Ω—Å—å–∫–∏–º defense‚Äë—Å—Ç–∞—Ä—Ç–∞–ø–∞–º, —Ç–∞–∫ —ñ –ø–∞—Ä—Ç–Ω–µ—Ä–∞–º —Ç–∞ –∑–∞–º–æ–≤–Ω–∏–∫–∞–º SAP –∫—Ä–∞—â–µ —Ä–æ–∑—É–º—ñ—Ç–∏, —è–∫ –ø—Ä–∞—Ü—é—é—Ç—å –≥–∞–ª—É–∑–µ–≤—ñ —Ä—ñ—à–µ–Ω–Ω—è SAP S/4HANA Defense & Security, –ª–æ–≥—ñ—Å—Ç–∏–∫–∞, —Ç–µ—Ö–Ω—ñ—á–Ω–µ –æ–±—Å–ª—É–≥–æ–≤—É–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—è —Ç–∞ Explosives Management
